 1. INTRODUCTION 1.1 China's economic reforms, initiated in 1978, were followed by rapid economic growth. The next critical step in the development of a market economy is the deepening of state-owned enterprises (SOE) reform, an area where other reforms-price, fiscal, financial, trade, investment, planning, legal, social and labor-interact. In November 1993, the Government announced a wide ranging reform program aimed at selected SOEs and 18 Municipalities. The experiment includes the adoption of new accounting standards, asset evaluation techniques and administrative regulations, corporatization, and comprehensive SOE restructuring, bankruptcy and divestiture of social services by the municipalities. 1.2 One of the obstacles to accelerating enterprise reform is the existence of large numbers of surplus workers in these enterprises. Of the 112 million workers employed in SOEs in 1994, the Ministry of Labor (MOL) estimates that 15 percent are redundant and the number is expected to rise. The pace of labor redeployment, however, is also slowed by the role enterprises have played in the delivery of basic social services such as housing, pensions and medical benefits. The absence of alternative social institutions for delivering these services has forced the Government to restrict enterprises from laying off redundant labor. Limited supporting employment services and lack of appropriate training programs for new skills have also significantly affected the pace of labor market development and mobility. Ongoing social and policy reforms addressing these issues will in the future give enterprises more discretion in redeploying surplus labor. 1.3 To assist China's effort in SOE reform, the Bank has provided assistance through economic and sector work and financing of investments to support restructuring and labor mobility. Various studies have outlined an SOE reform strategy framework, identified policy options to promote the development of the labor market and the strategy for meeting the growing demand for skilled labor. In collaboration with key Government agencies, the Bank has undertaken an in-depth review of SOEs in selected municipalities. In addition, a joint Government and Bank conference was held in Beijing in June 1995 to review the Government's policy options for enterprise reform. The Bank is also supporting the Government's effort in piloting housing and industrial reforms and the development of a social security system. 1.4 The proposed pilot project, aimed at the development of a labor market to promote labor mobility, complements the Bank's ongoing assistance to SOE reform. The proposed project was jointly prepared by the MOL and the five pilot municipalities (PMs) including Deyang, Guangzhou, Shaoxing with Zhejiang Province, Weifang and Wuhan (one of the 18 selected municipalities for comprehensive reform) with assistance of the Bank Group (See attached map). A Project Implementation Plan (PIP), from which key
 elements are presented in Annex 1, was prepared by the MOL and was reviewed in Washington with the representatives of the MOL and formed the basis for appraisal in July 1995.
 - 3 - 2. THE LABOR MARKET A. LABOR FORCE PROFILE 2.1 China's labor force is predominately rural. Out of a total labor supply of 620 million in 1994, 447 million were employed in rural areas of which most were engaged in agriculture. In urban areas, state-owned enterprises (SOEs) and collectives' continue to provide the great majority of jobs, and in 1993 accounted for 86 percent of urban employment. Statistically measured, unemployment is low by international standards at only 2.9 percent of the urban labor force in 1994-but, as demonstrated below, underemployment is much more severe. 2.2 In total, labor supply and demand growth rates closely matched each other since 1980, and the unemployment rate remained reasonably stable at a low level. There were, however, significant shifts in the composition of labor demand. In rural areas, liberalization of nonagricultural activities led to tremendous growth in off-farm employment in rural enterprises, and the share of such activities at the national level rose from 8.3 percent in 1980 to 24.2 percent by 1994. This was accompanied by a further shift in the allocation of labor within agriculture in favor of small-scale farming and away from agricultural collectives. In urban areas, an increased emphasis on growth in the private sector encouraged a shift in the composition of employment away from SOEs and collective-owned enterprises (COEs) and towards privately-owned and joint venture enterprises and self-employment. ln 1980, the urban private sector (private enterprises and self employment) accounted for less than 0.2 percent of total employment in China, but by 1994, this had grown to 3.7 percent. Table 2.1 presents China's labor force and employment profile. 2.3 These trends hide two major features of the Chinese labor market. First, there is substantial degree of underemployment. This takes two forms, large numbers of redundant workers in SOEs and COEs in urban areas and large and growing surplus labor within agriculture. Second, severe shortages of skilled workers have developed in the cities, and the Township and Village Enterprises (TVEs) are also short of skilled labor. The labor market is thus characterized by an excess supply of unskilled workers and an excess demand for skilled labor. China has three types of enterprises: state-owned (SOEs); collective-owned (COEs); and privately owned. Technically, COEs are owned by the employees, but are, in practice, administered by lower-level tiers of government. For most practical purposes the distinction between SOEs and COEs has become highly blurred, although SOEs still tend to be larger, more capital-intensive and more diversified than COEs.
 - 4 - 2.4 Public enterprises in China are overstaffed. MOL's estimates indicate that, in the SOEs, at least 15 percent of their work force or 16.8 million employees could be made redundant with little or no impact on productive capacity. It is further estimated that about 80 percent of SOEs have a labor surplus ranging between 15 and 80 percent of their employment levels with only a few SOEs having 80 percent. There is also an unknown number of surplus workers in COEs. This is not a new development, as overstaffing in public enterprises arose in the pre-reform system when enterprises had an obligation to hire workers as directed by the Government. However, as public enterprises were increasingly evaluated on the basis of the commercial performance faced by enterprises in a market economy, the level of redundancy among their work forces became more and more apparent. Reforms in the 1 980s did little to change the situation, as managers still faced soft budget constraints, and could maintain overstaffing levels, but more recent moves to expose SOEs to commercial criteria mean that the continued employment of redundant workers will become impossible without further subsidies. This problem, while less visible in the past, may have worsened as employment in the SOEs and COEs continued to grow in the 1980s and 1990s, despite increasing access to labor-saving technology from abroad in many industries. Recently, state enterprises have laid-off surplus workers at lower pay. If the number of surplus workers in SOEs were added to official estimates of urban unemployment, the measured unemployment rate would rise drastically to about 11.5 percent. When applying the labor requirements approach , the Chinese authorities estimate that about 30 percent of agricultural labor is surplus. 2.6 Shortages of skilled workers have emerged following rapid growth in the economy over the past decade. National trends are reflected to different degrees in the experience of the five cities selected for the proposed pilot project. Of the five, only Guangzhou, situated in a rapidly growing area in Southern China, is in the enviable position of finding labor demand growing faster than supply after adjusting for growth of surplus workers in enterprises and rural areas. Guangzhou's fast growing economy is experiencing a rapid reduction of rural surplus workers as they are absorbed into urban and off-farm rural activities. All five cities however, are experiencing difficulties in redeploying redundant workers from state enterprises. Even in Guangzhou, where GDP growth of 13 percent a year is rapidly opening up new jobs, it is not easy to provide redundant workers with the skills needed to compete in the local labor market. Skill shortages are emerging in all five cities given growing industrial demand for skilled labor. B. LABOR MOBILITY 2.7 The current policy regarding the disposition of surplus workers still emphasizes maintaining social stability. In implementing reform measures, therefore, local governments must carefully monitor the socially affordable level of unemployment in light of the strength of the local economy. Government policy makers recognize that this is inefficient, but the social security system is not yet adequately developed to handle significantly larger open unemployment rates. Moreover, labor mobility is restricted by residence permit requirements, enterprise-based basic social services, limited employment services, and lack of training programs to meet the demand for new skills. However, due to growing labor shortages particularly in the fast growing coastal regions of China, the urban registration requirements is not strictly enforced leading to the burgeoning 'floating population'. 2.8 Recent labor and wage reforms are providing more incentives to improve efficiency and increase labor mobility. These include the labor contract system, abolition of job assignment by the state, and reforms in the wage system that strengthen the links between performance and wage determination. It is expected that these reformns will boost the demand for quality training programs, in contrast to the passive, supply-driven programs of the past. Social security reform at present focuses on: (a) relieving the individual enterprises of their social security responsibilities by making these services available outside the enterprises; (b) enlarging the social security premium pool to 2 The labor requirements approach first sets a norm for agricultural labor productivity, and then calculates labor requirements by applying the norm to actual output. By 1992, 80 percent of the total social insurance expenditure in China is accounted for by SOEs. Pooling of social insurance covering all workers would be a long term undertaking. Only 26 percent of SOE workers are on contract. Labor turnover was still very low at I percent. China's approach to economic and social reform is based on piloting new measures. The proposed project is also designed to pilot the impact of providing employment and training services supported by an enabling legal framework for labor market development and mobility. C. EMPLOYMENT SERVICES 2.9 Public Employment Services (ES) operate at all administrative levels although the major responsibility for the Service is at the Province level, through Labor Service Bureaus (LSBs). Lower level LSBs operate in Cities, Districts or Counties and limited services are provided at the neighborhood, township and village level Employment Stations. National policies for the ES are set by MOL. In total, there are about 4,000 LSBs throughout the country, targeting primarily the urban and, more particularly, City areas. The Employment Service operates four types of outlets: (a) Employment Exchange Centers (EECs) responsible for job brokerage; (b) Unemployment Insurance (UI) to administer unemployment benefits; (c) Employment Training Centers responsible for retraining those registered as unemployed; and (d) Labor Service Companies (LSCs) providing a mix of employment services and creating employment. Job Brokerage 2.10 There are an estimated 2,400 EECs. The Centers register unemployed people and vacancies and provide limited labor market information at nominal charges. They operate as "markets" where employers and job seekers come together to negotiate directly. No screening of job applicants is undertaken and there is little counseling of registrants. Negotiations between employers and job seekers usually take place on-site and agreed contracts are then registered at the Center. Although the MOL has been computerizing services in 14 cities and some sites have operating independent computer systems, the majority of the services are provided manually. About 50 percent of all vacancies are estimated to be handled by the ES. At present employers are required to register their vacancies with the ES but as other private employment agencies develop and as enterprises are released from government controls on employing people, the ES will need to provide more market oriented services competitively and diversify its operations.
 -7- Unemployment Insurance 2.11 UI is collected through a payroll-based levy which, until recently, was restricted to SOEs. Coverage is now being extended to other forms of enterprise and to rural areas. UI is payable only to unemployed people who have been displaced from enterprises covered by the system and only in the area where they were employed. Entitlements are not transferable between Cities nor from rural to urban areas. Progress is being made to incorporate mobility provisions into the system especially since UI contributions are now being pooled at municipal levels for later disbursement to Districts and Counties within the Province. Ul contributions may be used to finance benefit payments, administration of the Employment Service and training of unemployed workers. The MOL now requires that 15 percent of the UI fund be used for retraining of surplus and unemployed workers. Assistance may also be provided direct to SOEs with surplus workers and for small business assistance. Other Functions 2.12 Apart from its two core functions, the ES performs other limited functions. It provides some labor market analysis and information but given the lack of any adequate computerized data base, these are very limited. The MOL maintains national information (published in the annual Year Book of Labor Statistics) and the information held at lower levels of the Service is sparse and probably unreliable. The MOL has limited capacity to analyze data and publish and disseminate findings on labor market activities and employment trends. Few labor market studies such as forecasting or industry and occupation studies are undertaken. Little administrative information is available, particularly financial data concerning the operations of the ES. 2.13 The ES offers some support to restructuring SOEs, although this support is essentially passive-limited subsidies to wages to enable SOEs to retain surplus workers or subsidies towards setting up surplus workers in enterprise subsidiaries known as Labor Service Companies (LSC) which operate as collectives on the fringes of the SOEs. The LSCs, though under state supervision, enjoy some autonomy as labor exchanges and as centers for job training and creation by setting up their independent enterprises. They perform distinct functions including: (a) the development and implementation of the labor plan; (b) employment services which would otherwise not be available in their localities, including registration of job vacancies, guidance, organization of training and periodic labor markets, and promotion of labor mobility; and (c) operating enterprises designed to create employment. There are no other forms of assistance (such as training packages or financial support towards retraining within SOEs) nor are there any standard methodologies (such as establishing local or SOE restructuring committees) for assisting enterprises going through restructuring. No standard materials are available to support these approaches. 2.14 In effect, the bulk of the responsibility for placing surplus workers falls on the enterprises themselves. As a result, the scope of ES activities has been limited to the
 small number of workers who are laid off. As open unemployment increases, the ESs will be required to play a larger and more active role in job placement. At the same time, the need for comprehensive income support and reemployment policies (on labor marke, information, counseling, placement services and retraining programs) will also become increasingly compelling. The proposed pilot project is designed to enhance the Employment Service capacities to actively provide support to SOE reform. D. SKILL DEVELOPMENT SERVICES 2.15 The demand for in-service training is met mainly from three sources. Most large and some medium-sized state enterprises have a training institution for their own employees designated as Enterprise Training Centers (ENTCs). Skilled workers schools (SWSs) are under the general administration of the MOL and are managed by central technical bureaus, local labor bureaus, and enterprises. The primary function of SWSs is preservice training, but many also run in-service training programs for mid-level and senior technicians. I,ocal labor bureaus also run Employment Training Centers (ETCs) that deliver short-term training. In addition to these sources, the demand for in-service training is attracting other suppliers to the market, including some in the private sector. 2.16 These training institutions are characterized by: (a) Low Internal Efficiency. Utilization of workshops and laboratories is generally low, mostly because of the lack of appropriate equipment, a shortage of consumable materials used in practice training, and shortcomings in curricula design and instructional management. Instructional staff have very low teaching loads, both as stipulated by regulation and in practice. Many of the institutions have significant excess capacity. (b) Severe Resource Limitations. This is one of the most critical factors contributing to low internal efficiency. The limitations are particularly severe for the purchase of instructional materials, consumable materials for practice training, tools and equipment. Vocational training is by nature substantially more costly than general education. Given limited direct cost recovery, the training institutions depend on their sponsoring government bureaus or enterprises for resources. (c) Limited Industrial Experience of Teaching Staff. While the academic training of teachers is in general satisfactory, many teachers lack adequate industrial experience. In addition, their teaching techniques consist predominantly of lectures and some demonstration, and they are not familiar with other pragmatic and effective techniques suitable for vocational training, such as audiovisual and computer-based teaching techniques, simulation technology, and use of performance-based objectives. As the curricula and teaching materials are revised to make use of these techniques, the teachers should also receive training in these areas.
 - 9 - (d) Inadequate Instructional Material, Curriculum, and Teaching Methods. The training curriculum and methods of instruction are not well- suited to the needs of surplus workers and rural migrants who lack basic education and skills needed to facilitate retraining. Adults demand training that permits them to enter training on short notice and to return quickly to employment when desired competencies have been achieved. Modular, competency-based curricula and teaching methods that create this flexibility are not available from current sources of training such as ETCs, which stress short-term training. Teaching techniques in all sources of in-service training consist predominantly of lectures and some demonstration. Modern techniques of instruction using audiovisual, computer-based teaching, and simulation technology are not used. Outside ENTCs, instructors lack industrial experience. While there are pockets of excellence with well- organized and equipped schools and training centers, the overall picture is one of out-dated facilities and equipment and poorly equipped laboratories and practice facilities. (e) Uncertain External Efficiency. External efficiency appears high, as attested by the high percentage of graduates who are placed in jobs, and the evidence of a continuing exchange of views among the training institutions, employers, and government. However, this could simply be a reflection of an absolute shortage of most types of skilled labor and of in-service training slots, or the government's policy on full employment. When a more open labor market develops, wages are decontrolled, and managers have a better understanding of the operational costs and benefits of creating a skilled work force, more conventional measures of external efficiency could be applied. In the meantime, it is important to ensure that mechanisms to encourage and demonstrate good training, and to engage local managers in determining and applying training policy, are put in place. (f) Inadequate Management, Planning, and Coordination. Each type of training institution has formal and informal links with the enterprise, industry, or district it serves. These links facilitate communication between individual institutions and employers or government regarding course content, policy, labor market needs, etc. However, on a sector-wide basis, there is greater scope for strengthening management, planning, and coordination mechanisms. Given the tendency of individual training institutions to act as isolated entities serving only the sponsoring enterprise, technical bureau, or district, there is a notable lack of sector-wide coordination between employers and government and the three different types of training institutions and thus there is no complete local database of allocation of training places. 2.17 As a result of these weaknesses, the movement to a market economy will require changes in the way skills training is organized, financed and delivered. The concept of
 - 10- life-time employment is disappearing and with it labor mobility will become more important. This is already evident in the rising demand for in-service training. Opening of the economy will bring more changes in technology and pressures for improving productivity. These changes will require a more flexible training system, one that can adapt quickly to new skill demands generated by changing markets and technologies and that can deliver cost-effective training to workers as they enter their first jobs, but also on a continuing basis throughout their careers. New policies defining the roles of the state and nonstate sectors in providing skills training will be required and the present system will need to be reformed. To improve the utilization rates of training facilities, complementary inputs (consumable materials, etc.) would have to be provided, by raising cost recovery, leasing the facilities and equipment to other entities when they are not being used, or shutting down training centers that prove too inefficient to maintain (i.e. those for which there is insufficient demand). At the same time, access to external training institutions by workers of small or loss-making enterprises which no longer find it profitable to operate their own ENTCs should be ensured. The need to improve instructional material, curriculum and teaching methods, and to train teaching staff in their use, remains, regardless of the pace of enterprise reform. However, the case to strengthen the planning and coordination mechanism would become stronger, since as enterprises gain more autonomy over their activities, opportunities for contact between government and industries become fewer, and without coordination there is a risk that different entities could be duplicating efforts in the field of vocational training where scale economies make such duplication inefficient. The proposed project would enhance the efficiency of resource allocation to training providers by introducing a transparent and market-driven funding mechanism and involving municipal government departments, employers and trade associations in policy development and governance of the training systems.
 - I I - 3. GOVERNMENT STRATEGY AND RECENT KEY REFORMS A. RECENT DEVELOPMENTS 3.1 The Government's objective for the labor market reform program is to move away from a state-administered system of labor allocation towards a market system while minimizing the inevitable transition costs. Toward this end, the reform of social insurance is a prerequisite. The Government's strategy is to concentrate on five main policy directions. First, encouraging rural labor absorption through further development of the TVEs. Second, encouraging all forms of productive and service sector employment growth in the towns. Third, expanding and improving urban labor market services. Fourth, progressively allowing the market to determine wages and remove barriers to labor mobility within the cities. Fifth, alleviating skill shortages. These policy directions will be empowered through appropriate legislation. In addition, further legislation is planned to meet the International Labor Office (ILO) standards regarding free collective bargaining and working conditions. Since 1980, the Government has initiated a series of reformns providing the basis for the development of the labor market. Labor Contract System 3.2 Prior to the introduction of contracts governing the period and conditions of service for new recruits, urban workers in wage employment were on a job-for-life basis. Significant progress has since been made in moving workers to contract status, and in all types of enterprises and in all the PMs most of the workers are now employed on this basis. This represents an important potential improvement in labor mobility. The maximum contract period is about five years. Temporary regulations have been issued by the MOL regarding special categories such as temporary and seasonal workers. 3.3 While progress in this area is impressive it should be further accelerated. Under the proposed project, PMs plan to transfer all workers to contract status by specified dates-Deyang (end-1996), Guangzhou (end-1995), Shaoxing (already completed end- 1993), Weifang (end-1994), Wuhan (end-1995). Implementation in each PM is coordinated by a committee headed by the mayor and including representatives of the Labor Bureau, the Party, employers and trade unions. Optimal Labor Reorganization 3.4 To combat the underemployment problem in state enterprises, the government introduced the Optimal Labor Reorganization (OLR) program on a nationwide basis in 1989. OLR aims to eliminate surplus labor in enterprises through attrition and retraining,
 - 12 - and covered about 10.5 million workers by mid-1992. Under OLR, all remaining workers would be encouraged to move on to a labor contract status. In practice, enterprises have tended to freeze recruitment of new workers and reduce overstaffing through natural attrition, and, in more extreme cases, offer fully-paid retraining to some surplus workers in the hope that they will move voluntarily to another job. So far the net effects of these approaches has been to put first-time job seekers at a further disadvantage as fewer vacancies are available without much reduction in the number of surplus workers. Consequently, it is now common for affected state enterprises to establish labor service companies with satellite enterprises as a means of redeploying surplus employees and employing new labor market entrants. Although China enacted a bankruptcy law that could be used in respect of insolvent state enterprises, it has not been applied widely. Wage Reforms 3.5 Several key reforms in labor and wage policies in the 1980s have enabled individual enterprises and the labor market to pursue some degree of efficiency and flexibility, rather than security and rigidity. Wage reform linking remuneration to productivity helps to increase workers' initiative in obtaining better skills, in contrast to the supply-driven, passive attitude toward training in the past. Wage reform has taken place in the form of reintroduction of piece rates and bonuses, thus linking remuneration to productivity and allowing enterprises to distribute part of the after-tax profit as bonuses. Following the adoption of the Labor Law in January 1995 (para. 3. 10) the MOL and, in some cases, the cities, intend to issue regulations concerning: (a) the distribution of different forms of remuneration to workers within enterprises; (b) minimum wages; and (c) aggregate control of the wage bill. These reformns are intended to accelerate the labor reform process. The force of these new laws and regulations will be to: (i) monetize in-kind benefits such as transport and housing; and (ii) protect the lowest paid through minimum wages while ensuring that minimum rates do not significantly reduce employment. For the time being, increases in the wage bill of SOEs will continue to be tied to performance criteria while employers in non-SOE establishments will be allowed to set wages freely at levels above minimum rates without state control. Wage policy towards the SOEs will be reviewed as their financial position improves, and the economy moves closer to a market system. Social Insurance 3.6 Reforms in social insurance (pensions, unemployment and medical insurance) and housing have gradually moved in the direction of making these services available outside the enterprise sector. The guiding principles on which the individual reform steps in social insurance are based are to: (a) relieve the individual enterprises of their heavy social insurance responsibilities; (b) enlarge the social security premium pool, to reduce the financial risk to individual enterprises; (c) expand the coverage of these measures to all workers regardless of their status (permanent, contract, or temporary workers) or type of enterprise they work for; (d) introduce policy changes to improve the management and administration of the social security system to achieve economies of scale and better
 - 13 - efficiency. The enlarged pool will allow risks to be distributed across enterprises employing workers with different age and illness/injury profiles. Approaches taken or actively being considered for selected social insurance areas in several municipalities which are advanced in their reform of the social insurance delivery and housing system are summarized below. 3.7 To provide a social safety net for workers displaced by the application of budget constraints to enterprises, the government set up an unemployment insurance scheme in 1986. Eligibility requires that retrenchment arose from one of the following: (a) bankruptcy; (b) enterprise restructuring; (c) termination of labor contract; or (d) dismissal following a breach of the internal SOE rules. In addition to cash benefits, the scheme also provides training to the unemployed. At end-1993, the scheme covered about 90 percent of workers in state enterprises. 3.8 For health insurance, a system which would pool comprehensive health care benefits across all the enterprises in the municipality, and all types of workers will be developed. All industries would be covered in order to pool the risks associated with differences across industries both in proportion of retirees and of occurrences of certain medical conditions. 3.9 For housing reform, the overall objective is to expand the availability of commercialized housing and the establishment of a financially viable institutional framework to operate such a housing sector. A pilot project is being supported by the Bank to help four municipalities implement a strategy to develop a market-based housing system with a view to empowering the workers to rent or buy housing commercially. Lessons from similar projects in the transition economies in Europe and the former Soviet Union emphasize the importance of ensuring government ownership of the project in its design, the setting of realistic project goals, and careful monitoring and evaluation to guide mid-course adjustments. In China, the Vocational Technical Education (VTE) Project (Cr. 2114- CHA) illustrates the need for strong Government commitment to, and ownership of, policy reforms. Under the proposed pilot project, the joint proposals from the MOL and PMs for policy and legal reform reflect their priorities and the Bank facilitated in reaching consensus. The importance of developing clear protocols to guide project implementation and management where inter- agency cooperation is needed is also noted. During project preparation, the Bank was actively involved in providing selected technical assistance and bringing international experience to the preparation workshops where central, provincial and municipal government officials participated. 3.12 The 1995 World Development Report reviewed lessons drawn from three types of policy responses by governments intended to speed the transition and ease the plight of displaced workers, as shown in Table 3.1: (a) reducing labor market rigidities; (b) assisting workers by equipping them to adapt to change; and (c) providing transfers to reduce income losses. Although lessons have been noted from the Bank's experience with policies to improve labor mobility in the transitional economies of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, these lessons are not totally relevant since China is different in one key aspect. Its GDP growth has averaged 9.6 percent annually from 1980 to 1993, compared with 2.9 percent for other low, middle and high income countries. It has the fastest growing economy in the world. Although much of the growth is concentrated in the coastal region, new investment is beginning to move inward. By contrast, experience with labor market policies to promote labor mobility in transition economies elsewhere has been in a climate of economic retrenchment. In other transition economies, as well as in Latin American and Middle Eastern Countries under adjustment, formal employment has fallen by/5 to 15 percent during the transition and real wages have decreased by more than 40 percent in extreme cases. 3.13 The Bank's experience with policies to ease employment restructuring should be interpreted against this background. The key difference is that unlike the transition economies of Central and Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, there are jobs in China for workers to move to. Fifteen years of gradualist reforms have produced this growth. Not all provinces and cities, however, share equally in this growth, and thus, some areas face labor surplus problems similar to those of other transition economies.

In the PMs, selected SOEs and training institutions would be traced to assess the impact of the project using the indicators described in Annex 9. Expanding the supply of training through budgetary appropriations or financing training demand through vouchers for training are possible options. Both these options were not selected to be piloted. Solely expanding training capacities was not chosen since it fails to respond to changing market demands. Similarly, the voucher system would assume a free market with information and no barriers to entry to provide training. These conditions do not prevail in the municipalities. Instead, the proposed inservice training financing mechanism is appropriate and captures the demand and supply sides based on competition and will ensure efficient allocation of resources guided by market conditions by promoting public and private training providers. The choice for employment services through the introduction of the labor market information system is also appropriate. With a growing demand for skilled labor along with a pool of surplus labor in SOEs, matching demand and supply with labor market information system and advising job seekers on the required skills are critical to labor redeployment efforts.

The appraisal of the training projects to be financed by the VTCC is based on the following criteria: (a) evidence of market demand; (b) willingness of employers and trainers to share the cost of training; (c) training that is six months or more dur Aion; (d) training targeted to priority sectors; (e) capacity of the pro Ader to deliver training of suitable quality and design; (f) cost of the training; and (g) such other criteria as the VTCC Board may deem appropriate. 21. Appraisal of Institutional and Enterprise Training Projects. The appraisal of institutional training projects is be made as follows: (a) Evidence of Market Demand (50 points). Proposals for VTCC funding submitted by public and private training organizations must contain evidence of market demand for the skills to be taught. Examples of this evidence include one or more of the following: (i) employer surveys identifying hard-to-fill job vacancies; (ii) trainee placement rates of similar training programs; (iii) help wanted ads, job vacancy listings; (iv) labor market statistics showing rising employment for the skills to be developed; and (v) employer job guarantees for trainees. (b) Willingness to Cost Share (25 points). Proposals indicating a willingness of the training institution or enterprise to share in the cost of the training will be given added weight in the appraisal process. The amount of cost sharing by the training institution or enterprise should be indicated in the proposal. (c) Duration of Training (25 points). The proposal should indicate the duration of the training program. Long-term training of six months or
 - 54 - ANNEX3 longer is given added weight in the appraisal process on grounds that capital market failures inhibit private investment in this type of training. (d) Targeting Priority Sectors (25 points). The VTCC may elect to allocate resources on the basis of sectoral balance or for strategic purposes to develop new industries. Proposals should indicate the economic sector for which the training is to be provided. (e) Reaching Target Populations (25 points). The proposal must indicate the number of persons to be trained, and from this the number that come from priority populations: surplus workers and rural to urban migrants. (f) Capacity to Deliver the Training (50 points). The proposal must contain evidence of the institution's capacity to deliver training of suitable quality and design for the priority populations: surplus workers and rural to urban migrants. Evidence of this capacity may include one or more of the following: (i) presence of full-time, professional management; (ii) appropriate facilities for instruction and practice; (iii) a training plan for enterprise trainers; (iv) modular, competency-based curriculum for institution', '-ainers; (v) qualified instructors; (vi) use of a standard financial accounting system; and (vii) share of previous trainees passing skills certifications exams. To be eligible for VTCC support, a training institution must be accredited by the Labor Bureau. 2. Cost of the Training (25 points). The proposal must itemize reimbursable costs .or training and administrative personnel, consumable materials used in instruction, rent and utilities, trainee transportation allowances, nondurable goods used in training, and depreciation of capital equipment (limited to 20 percent per year). Points are awarded for having competitive costs. 23. Proposals are evaluated on the criteria above and given a score. Each proposal is evaluated and scored independently by three VTCC training specialists. The low score and high score are dropped and the proposal is given the median score. Proposals with a median score of less than 125 points will not be accepted for funding by the VTF. Above this level, funding is based on the funds available and the ranking of proposals.

 - 75 - ANNEX 10 ANNEX 10: MONITORING, EVALUATION AND DISSEMINATION TERMS OF REFERENCE Background 1. China's economic reforms, initiated in 1978, have produced rapid economic growth. Over the past decade, China has experienced the fastest growing economy in the world averaging over 9 percent GDP growth per annum. Many state-owned enterprises (SOEs), however, have failed to share in this growth. Nearly half are losing money. The reform of these enterprises has become a priority. In November 1993, the Government announced a wide ranging reform program aimed at selected SOEs and 18 Municipalities. One of the obstacles to accelerating enterprise reform is the existence of large numbers of surplus workers in these enterprises. Of the 112 million workers employed in SOEs in 1994, the Ministry of Labor (MOL) estimates that 15 percent are redundant and the number is expected to rise. 2. The nation's labor market institutions are ill-prepared to assist in the redeployment of these surplus workers. The surplus worker problem is compounded by excess labor in rural areas. About 30 percent of agricultural labor is estimated by the MOL to be surplus. The current policy regarding the disposition of surplus workers emphasizes maintaining social stability. Labor mobility is restricted by residence permit requirements, enterprise-based social services, limited employment services, and lack of retraining programs to meet the demand for new skills. Labor reforrns, however, are lowering some of these ' ' to labor mobility. The proposed project would test the impact of providing employment and training services, supported by an enabling legal framework, on labor market development and mobility. Project Description 3. China's approach to economic and social reforms has been cautious and involves extensive piloting of new measures. The project will continue this pattern by piloting employment and training services in five municipalities: Deyang, Guangzhou, Shaoxing, Weifang, and Wuhan. The lessons from these cities are to be used throughout China to introduce successful employment service and training strategies to accelerate the redeployment of surplus labor. The proposed pilot project would contribute to an enabling environment for SOE reforms and promote China's transition to a market economy. The transfer of surplus labor from enterprises, where it is no longer demanded, to those where it can be used more productively while minimizing the potential for social instability is one of the ultimate objectives of SOE reforms.
 - 76 - ANNEX 10 4. The project's objectives are: (a) support policy and legal reforms to facilitate the development of fbnctioning labor markets and promote labor mobility; (b) improve the operation and management capacity of labor market services to provide redeployment assistance to enterprises, surplus workers in SOEs, and the unemployed and rural-to-urban migrant labor; (c) support the institutional reform for the management and delivery of effective in-service training for surplus workers in SOEs, the unemployed and rural to urban migrant labor to increase labor productivity and mobility; and (d) enhance the institutional capacity of project implementing agencies with a view to promoting market-based services. 5. These objectives would be achieved in the project by supporting labor market policy and legal reforms at the national level and introducing and testing employment services, including in-service training in the pilot municipalities. The pilot project would finance technical assistance to help the MOL prepare vital labor legislation and regulations in a niumber of areas key to the reform process. It would, in addition, finance the establishment of a labor market information system network in the MOL and pilot municipalities. The system would be able to match the qualifications of the job seeker with suitable openings and the collection of unemployment insurance contributions, the payment of benefits and the financial management of the program would be integrated in the labor market information system. 6. The project would also test a new policy framework using a training fund to improve the market orientation and quality of in-service vocational training. It would also support the establishment of an institutional capacity to plan effectively and manage efficiency a complete system of vocational training. At the national level, the project would strengthen the process of occupational standard setting, skills testing, and certification. These components will require considerable staff training and institutional capacity building. The project will therefore include local and overseas training and participation of MOL and pilot municipality labor bureau staff in study tours. This institutional development will also include consultant services to review existing organizational set-ups within labor bureaus and recommend strategies to improve effectiveness in delivering labor market services. Monitoring and Evaluation Task 7. The Terms of Reference (TOR) is to provide a monitoring and evaluation plan to extract lessons from the national and five pilot city projects. The plan should provide for a baseline of performance indicators for each of the project's four components against which comparisons can be made during implementation to determine if the project's
 - 77 - ANNEX 10 objectives are being achieved. The monitoring and evaluation plan should focus on three types of performance indicators: inputs, outputs, and outcome. Along with this, the plan should provide for monitoring of the implementation process to determine if the project is being implemented in keeping with its design. A dissemination plan is to accompany the monitoring and evaluation plan enabling the MOL and the PMs to transfer the knowledge gained from the pilot project to other provinces and cities. A panel of experts including local and foreign specialists would assist in dissemination workshops. Development and Implementation Strategy 9. A single, unified MED plan should be developed to cover the national and pilot city projects and their components. The plan, where possible, should include similar measures of performance indicators for each city to support comparative analysis of the five pilot city projects. It should also consider national and local needs for a management information system on project inputs and outputs. The monitoring and evaluation strategy should make maximum use of local consultants. Foreign consultants should be used where unique technologies are involved, not widely available in China, with the understanding that the plan in its training components should indicate how these evaluation technologies would be transferred during the course of the project. The evaluation of project impacts should emphasize the use of cost-effectiveness and cost-benefit analysis, especially for vocational training.

doc.abstracts: The Labor Market Development Project will contribute to an enabling environment for state-owned enterprise (SOE) reforms and promote China's transition to a market economy. The objectives of this four-year pilot project are to: 1) support policy and legal reforms to facilitate the development of functioning labor markets and promote urban labor mobility; 2) improve the delivery of labor market services, and training to facilitate the redeployment of, surplus workers in SOEs, the unemployed, and rural-to-urban migrant labor and thus increase labor productivity and mobility; and 3) enhance the institutional capacity of project implementing agencies with a view to promoting market-based services. The components of the project are: 1) policy reform on the coverage and pooling of social insurance at the municipal level, reduction of surplus labor in SOEs, and the monetization of social benefits by employers; 2) employment services on job waiting time, improved administrative and accounting procedures and timely payment of unemployment insurance, and improved labor market information and dissemination; 3) inservice training on placement rates and earnings; and 4) institutional development on improved services to job seekers and employers, and improved resource allocation for training based on market signals.
